author: Odeinoichus
title: CHI Powers End the Chima Theme.
review:
Set #71222 Fun Pack Laval: Legends of Chima was a great Theme, sadly it wasn’t nearly as popular as Ninjago or even Nexo Knights after the first year. So it’s nice to see LEGO include it as one of the LEGO IP worlds in LEGO Dimensions. Is Laval worth tracking down? We shall see.

Packaging

Set in the final season of the Theme, Laval’s artwork on the front of the box shows him wearing Fire Armour and using his flaming sword, he takes up so much space on the box you can’t really see the Chima world behind him which is still printed on the box despite being obscured by Laval’s character shot. Great looking packaging as always though.

Parts

Chima Fire Armour and Printed Flame powered Stud is included in this set, there are a few other nice Chima centric coloured elements, but nothing too rare.

Minifigures

Laval: This particular Minifigure is unique to the Fun Pack, the parts are mostly not unique as they are the same as seen in most of the Theme from that time, but the printed torso and legs are unique in colour and design, which is really great for Chima fans and collectors.

The build

Mighty Lion Ride: This is a truly awesome micro scaled vehicle from Chima, the build is oh so satisfying and works in capturing the likeness of the overall Lion themed vehicles from the main sets. Loved every moment building it.

Lion Blazer: Finally another pack that has distinct and unique alternate models, this second build is equally satisfying and fun compared to some of the more recent sets I’ve discussed.

Fire Lion: This build is pretty nice too, granted all of the builds are roughly five minutes to finish depending on how quickly you follow along with the instructions while pressing the advance button on the controller.

The completed model

Mighty Lion Ride: All three of the models are pretty accurate to their in-game digital counterparts. Each model also works great on or off the toy tag as a display item or to play with. The MLR can detach and roll around on four wheels.

Lion Blazer: It’s a really nice secondary model and a great design which manages to look different while using all of the same parts, not all of the sets can pull this off very well, but most of the vehicle builds tend to look great and work well in either of their three builds.

Fire Lion: Spewing flams this model looks like Laval’s trusty fire themed assault vehicle… I plum forgot the name of it. All three work great and I’m having a hard time saying which one is my favorite, I’d suggest getting the parts to build all three and decide for yourself which version is the best of the best. None of them can have a driver though.

The Digital Content

The Adventure World: This is Chima, a world full of places to visit and puzzles to solve while collecting Gold Bricks. The Adventure World of Chima is a personal favorite of mine because of the many fun characters and interesting architecture. Note that the voice work is slightly altered from the actual cartoon as the cartoon voices were not recorded for Dimensions.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: Laval is capable of absorbing CHI from CHI Fountains and unlocking CHI Pedestals when unleashing his CHI. When fully powered up he can destroy Cracked LEGO Objects, he also has the Acrobat, Laser Deflector and Sonar Smash abilities.

The MLR can activate Accelerator Switches, when upgraded into the Lion Blazer it can use Tow Bars and has a Special Attack. The Fire Lion has a Special Weapon ability, but doesn’t seem to offer much else, while the models are great their in-game abilities are a bit lacking compared to some of the other vehicles in the game.

Overall opinion

Laval is fun, if you’re a fan you’ll want to get him, however if you’re only interested in purchasing the minimum number of characters and packs in order to unlock everything than he’s not the one to get for Legends of Chima World, as we’re about to discuss there is another better option. Mildly recommended for fans of Chima.
